analysis.title: Selma
analysis.author: Paul Webb
analysis.logline: Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. leads a dangerous voting rights campaign in Selma, Alabama, confronting brutal racism and challenging President Johnson to pass landmark civil rights legislation.

concept.justification: Powerful historical narrative exploring a pivotal moment in civil rights movement with clear dramatic stakes and national significance

structure.justification: Masterful three-act structure tracking King's strategic campaign, with clear dramatic progression and mounting tension

protagonist.justification: Martin Luther King Jr. is deeply complex - simultaneously strategic leader, moral voice, and vulnerable human struggling with immense pressure

supporting_cast.justification: Rich ensemble of distinct characters including Abernathy, Young, Johnson, and local activists, each with compelling individual arcs

dialogue.justification: Extraordinary dialogue capturing historical figures' voices, laden with subtext, mixing political rhetoric with personal vulnerability

genre_execution.justification: Masterful historical drama that balances intimate character moments with sweeping political narrative

originality.justification: Fresh perspective on well-known historical events, revealing strategic complexity behind civil rights movement

target_audience.note: Broad appeal across ages interested in social history

cast_attachability.note: Multiple prestigious roles for leading actors

marketing_hook.note: Powerful true story with clear visual marketing potential

budget_return_ratio.note: Low production costs, high cultural significance

comparable_success.note: Similar to critically and commercially successful historical dramas

structure_analysis.act_breaks: Act 1: Establishing Selma context, Act 2: Escalating protest strategy, Act 3: National confrontation and legislative victory

characters.protagonist: Martin Luther King Jr. - Charismatic civil rights leader seeking voting rights through strategic non-violent resistance
characters.antagonist: Composite of racist institutions: Jim Clark, George Wallace, systemic racism
supporting: Ralph Abernathy - King's loyal friend and strategic partner
Coretta King - Supportive yet challenging spouse

standout_scenes.scene: Johnson's voting rights speech to Congress
standout_scenes.why: Powerful dramatic climax revealing political transformation
Visceral depiction of non-violent resistance against violent oppression

comparable_films.title: 12 Years a Slave
comparable_films.similarity: Unflinching historical drama about racial injustice

comparable_films.title: Lincoln
comparable_films.similarity: Political narrative about transformative legislative moment

budget_tier.justification: Period piece with multiple locations and large ensemble cast

assessment.recommendation_rationale: Exceptional screenplay with near-perfect execution, demonstrating extraordinary craft across all dimensions. Weighted score of 8.65 with zero critical failures and maximum commercial viability.

film_now_assessment.lightning_test: Opening scene of racially charged tension in small-town Alabama immediately establishes high stakes
goosebumps_moments: Page 12: Annie Lee Cooper's powerful resistance at voter registration
Page 226: King's inspiring speech about moral courage
film_now_assessment.career_risk_test: Absolutely - this screenplay represents transformative storytelling about a crucial historical moment
film_now_assessment.legacy_potential: Extremely high - captures a pivotal moment in American civil rights history with nuance and power

analysis.verdict_statement: FILM NOW: Selma represents exceptional material that demands immediate greenlight consideration. The Lightning: A visceral exploration of strategic non-violent resistance against systemic racism. The Craft: Weighted score of 8.65 with no dimension below 8. The Commercial Case: CVS of 18/18. Multiple star-making roles for leading actors. Urgency: This screenplay will not remain available.
